Title: Applying virtual reality to teach the software development process to novice software engineers
Author(s): U Gulec, M Yilmaz, V Isler, PM Clarke
Venue: The Institute of Engineering and Technology
Impact (WHY): Development of a VR application, which simulates a practical work environment for software engineering students to gain experience from. Research also includes a test on the effectiveness of the environment/application
Implementation: Generates a 3D virtual office, and generates scenario's for the project to (virtually) work on. System consists of the "Requirements Analysis", "Design", "Implementation", "Test", and "Maintenance" phases
Evaluation: Pre and post test, and validation interviews
Results/findings: Both research questions are satisfied; students using the VR-based environment had higher increases of their knowledge than the control group. Also, the results showed that the training platform was able to motivate the students

Title: Collaborative Software Modelling in Virtual Reality
Author(s): E Yigitbas, S Gorissen, N Weidmann, G Engels
Venue: ACM/IEEE International Conference on Model Driven Engineering Languages and Systems
Impact (WHY): Developed a VR application (VmodlR) to improve collaboration in software modelling (creating UML diagrams)
Implementation: Implemented as a Unity Virtual environment with a grass plane and blue sky, onto which a 3D UML diagram is displayed, along with any other users as Virtual Characters.
Evaluation: Users executed tasks in VmodlR and in LucidChart, and usability metrics were collected
Results/findings: VR application scores more negatively in all aspects but for user satisfaction/experience.
Considered related work: Collaborative modelling: different kinds of UML or diagram editors, with differing capabilities for collaboration. 3D modelling: researches about visualizing UML in 3D, VisAr3D. Immersive modelling in AR/VR: some tools, but without networking/collaboration

Title: Comparative Study of an Augmented Reality Software Development Kit Suitable for Forensic Medicine Education
Author(s): K Tongprasom, W Boongsood, W Boongsood, T Pipatchotitham
Venue: International Journal of Information and Education Technology
Impact (WHY): Compares existing AR frameworks/libraries, and evaluates which are suitable for Forensic Medicine
Aspect of Software Engineering: Compares existing AR frameworks (albeit, not according to any SE-related metrics or requirements)
Implementation: Requirements for the best framework are: both 2D and 3D object recognition, recognition stability of movable and immovable markers, and exists for both Android and iOS
Results/findings: Vuforia is best suited as an AR framework for forensic medicine education

Title: Towards immersive software archaeology/ regaining legacy systems' design knowledge via interactive exploration in virtual reality
Author(s): A Hoff, M Nieke, C Seidl
Venue: ACM Joint Meeting on European Software Engineering Conference and Symposium on the Foundations of Software Engineering
Impact (WHY): Proposes a VR based visualization tool for software systems, with the aim of retaining system knowledge, and thereby minimzing legacy systems. "Immersive software archeology"
Software visualization metaphor (if appl: Planets, cities, and buildings for structural aspects, sub-components, and classes
Implementation: Immersion (experiencing the system): planets, cities, buildings, first-person-view, etc., exploration (navigation and orientation): zooming, semantic zooming (Google Maps style), , guidance (fostering understanding): ways in which the user can get an immediate idea of complexity. etc., coalescence (mental & technical back-link): POI's and annotations
Evaluation: Prototype has not been developed yet, so no evaluation yet
Considered related work: Existing software system analysis tools, and 2/3D software visualization research
Important references:
Visualization of the Static Aspects of Software: A
 Survey (2011), An Overview of 3D Software Visualization.
Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics (2009), Reverse Engineering: A Roadmap (2000), Re-implementing a Legacy System (2019)

Title: To VR or not to VR/ Is virtual reality suitable to understand software development metrics?
Author(s): D Moreno
Venue: International Symposium on Empirical Software Engineering and Measurement
Impact (WHY): An experiment that tries to show whether VR screens are acutally more effective at displaying SE-related data visualizations, compared to traditional 2D screens
Implementation: Experiment in which participants are to answer a number of questions using either the 2D visualization or the VR environment, and where the time to answer and correctness are measured. Uses Kibana (2D) and BabiaXR as tools for the experiment. GrimoireLab is used to collect metrics about a software code repository
Evaluation: Confounding variables for the experiment which are taken into account: experience with Kibana, experience with VR, experience in software development, position (practitioner, academic, student)

Title: WebAssembly enables low latency interoperable augmented and virtual reality software
Author(s): BB Khomtchouk
Impact (WHY): Concludes that a web-based AR/VR solution in Wasm is performant enought to not impact usability greatly. They suggest that the current WebXR standards in plain JS are - while the improvements have been impressive - not optimized enough. Do this in the form of an overview on the current state of WebXR, Wasm, and their existing combinations
Evaluation: Benchmarking of a face recognition library, with (1) the algorithm in JS, (2) the algorithm in OpenCV, and compiled down asm.js, and (3), the alogrithm in OpenCV, and compiled down to Wasm
Results/findings: Wasm had about twice as high of a framerate as asm.js, and twenty times that of the JS implementation. They also - plausibly - conclude that better performance will lead to more (economical) interest in WebXR and Wasm, which will in turn stimulate growth of and development of the technologies. They therefore suggest to (1): integrate Wasm in WebXR and more AR libraries, and (2): standardizing a web framework based on WebXR and Wasm

Title: Unleashing the potentials of immersive augmented reality for software engineering
Author(s): L Merino, M Lungu, C Seidl
Venue: IEEE International Conference on Software Analysis, Evolution and Reengineering
Impact (WHY): Researches numerous ways software engineering could possibly make use of/benefit from Immersive Augmented Reality
Aspect of Software Engineering: General; researches possible ways in which software engineering could benefit from IAR
Implementation: Envisioned context here - and assumption - is that the IAR headset will completely replace the traditinal computer. Takes eight usage scenario categoaries; collaboration, mobility, multi-device, pervasiveness,  privacy. Then, a number of envisioned usage scenario's are explained, in the areas of: Requirements Engineering, Software Design, Implementation, DevOps,
Results/findings: The "embodiment" and "mediated reality" aspects of IAR can be of benefit to almost all aspects of software engineering. Some challenges are also identified; for example: domain specific interaction techniques for software modelling and code writing, and the potential change in behaviour for software developers.
Considered related work: Work on software architecture visualization, software performance metric and comprehension visualization, exporing UML diagrams through HoloLens,  boosting motivation, boosting engagement
Notes: This paper identifies a bunch of hypothetical scenario's, and doesn't contribute any concrete, real work

Title: An augmented reality-based software architecture to support military situational awareness
Author(s): A Mitaritonna, MJ Abasolo
Venue: International Conference on Electrical, Communication and Computer Engineering
Impact (WHY): Developed an AR software architecture for situational awareness (SA) training
Technical contributions: RAIOM: a military AR-based architecture to support SA
Considered related work: The digital soldier/Future Soldiers, military projects in reference 5 (Eyekon, BARS, iARM , Ultra-Vis)
Notes: Isn't really about Software Engineering, more about military software

Title: MVC-3DC/ Software architecture model for designing collaborative augmented reality and virtual reality systems
Author(s): S Benbelkacem, N Zenati
Venue: Journal of King Saud University - Computer and Information Sciences
Impact (WHY): Devised an architecture (MVC-3DC) for collaborative AR/VR software

Title: Identifying Usability Issues of Software Analytics Applications in Immersive Augmented Reality
Author(s): D Baum, S Bechert, U Eisenecker, I Meichsner, R Muller
Venue: Working Conference on Software Visualization
Impact (WHY): Tries to improve adoption and usage of AR software visualization by identifying current usability issues in state-of-the-art AR visualization applications
Implementation: A number of participants were provided a setup of a visualization of JUnit through a HoloLens, and were asked a number of questions based on their interactions. The questions were divided in categories: Help & Setup, Visualization, and Dialog. Three iterations of evalutions were performed, and after each iteration, the feedback would be implemented for the next.
Evaluation: The three evaluation were performed, where improvements were made for each next evaluation, based on the feedback of the previous. Resulting in (for example), voice control, tutorials, and adjusted dialogs.
Results/findings: The problems that the particiapants had, usually had nothing to do with the visualization or the city metaphor, but were all to do with conventional user interface elements in AR. It also shows that usability was most impacted by guidance of the user in the application, rather than the visualization or the metaphor.
Considered related work: SkyscrapAR city metaphor software visualization. Builds on the research of Merino et al about the usability of AR  for software analytics

Title: Visualization of Evolution of Component-Based Software Architectures in Virtual Reality
Author(s): EF Heidmann, L von Kurnatowski, A Meinecke, A Schreiber
Venue: Working Conference on Software Visualization
Impact (WHY): Attempts to improve existing software visualization by adding visual indicators on how a software projects has evolved (i.e., its history)
Technical contributions: An extenstion to the existing IslandViz software
Implementation: Extension of IslandViz, where an enhanced alogrithm for the placement of islands had been devised, which takes their average positions throughout history into account. Also, tiles of the island (representing software bundles/compilation units) where raised depending on how long they existed.
Evaluation: The researchers had gathered a number of participant users, who had to perform a few tasks using regular IslandViz, and IslandViz with their extension. They compared the results of those few tasks, in which users where asked to answer questions about a piece of software (which packages/bundles had been added and removed over time).
Results/findings: The extension proves to have a positive effect on the times in which users could perform exploratory tasks. Also, comprehension of the software was improved. Usability was rated very similarly as without the extension.
Considered related work: City, solar system, and island metaphors for software visualizations. Lanza[19], Hassan et al.[20], Gall et al.[21], Steinbrucker and Lewerentz[22].

Title: Multi-Agent Software Architecture for Distributed Virtual Reality Systems
Author(s): V Duchenchuk, V Boublik
Venue: International Conference on Advanced Computer Information Technologies
Impact (WHY): Development of a software architecture for multi-agent DVR applications (which find usage in applications for education, simulation, training, and entertainment); and therefore easing the development of those kinds of applications
Technical contributions: An architecture fir multi-agent distributed VR applications
Implementation: Architecture for the multi-agent system consists of: Users, who make use of LobbyAgent, ConnectionAgent, UserAgent, ObjectAgent, TimeAgent
Evaluation: Proposed architecture is being developed and evaluated
Considered related work: Mobile agent systems: Aglets, Odyssey, Concordia, Voyager

Title: On the use of virtual reality in software visualization/ The case of the city metaphor
Author(s): S Romano, N Capece, U Erra, G Scanniello, M Lanza
Venue: Information and Software Technology
Impact (WHY): Research on the benefits of virtual reality as a tool for software visualization, and the usage of the city metaphor for software visualization and software comprehension
Implementation: Research was set up as an experiment with plenty of participants, each performing a number of software code comprehension tasks, where the (correctness) score was measured, along with the time in which they performed it. Each participant used either the Code2City, Code2CityVR, or Eclipse (Metrics and Smells plugin) tools for these tasks
Evaluation: Measurement of a correctness score on the execution of a number of tasks, the time in which they were completed, and a PANAS questionnaire
Results/findings: The results show that the correctness of the tasks, and the time in which they were completed, was significantly better for Code2City and Code2CityVR, compared to the Eclipse plugin. Also, while the PANAS questionnaire showed very similar results for Code2City and Code2CityVR, the VR variant showed to have significantly lower times in which the tasks were completed.
Considered related work: CodeCity, ExplorViz, SkyscrapAR, CityVR, research from Merino et al. about the city metaphor in numerous display methods
Important references: Merino et al., Wettal et al.

Title: Software framework for customized augmented reality headsets in medicine
Author(s): F Cutolo, B Fida, N Cattari, V Ferrari
Venue: IEEE Access
Impact (WHY): Developed an AR headset and an accompanying software architecture that is usable in healthcare (surgeries, for example)
Aspect of Software Engineering: Software architecture, development of software tools/packages
Technical contributions: An AR software framework for healthcare usage (also, the AR_VideoCapture, AR_Engine, and AR_Tracking libraries)
Implementation: Hardware: two camera, and two displays which can be turned on or off, making the headset a OST/VST hybrid. Software implemented in CUDA, and consists of AR_VideoCapture, AR_Engine, and AR_Tracking, which take of capturing images from the RGB cameras, augmenting and rendering them on the displays, and tracking the pose of the target with respect to the HMD, respectively
Evaluation: User study in which participants were tasked with tracing B-spline curves using the headset with AR guidance, and with the naked eye, measuring completion time, accuracy results. Also, a qualitative evaluation was performed to measure the usability of the headset
Results/findings: Qualitative: very positive scores for enjoyability and ease-of-use. Quantatively: statisically not significantly lesser than the control scenerio, which is an ideal scenario. Therefore, the quantative usability scored very promisingly

Title: Using Augmented Reality in Software Engineering Education? First insights to a comparative study of 2D and AR UML modeling
Author(s): R Reuter, F Hauser, D Muckelbauer, T Stark, E Antoni, J Mottok, C Wolff
Venue: Hawaii International Conference on System Sciences
Impact (WHY): Researches whether and to what extent the use of AR in modelling with UML is suitable for students in software engineering. Also development of a tool for integrating AR in software engineering teaching
Implementation: The software tool is a UML editing tool with both a 2D and AR interface. To test it out, and to test the main goal of the research, an experiment was held in which participants had to carry out modelling tasks (with one group performing them in 2D, and the other in AR), along with a self-assessment, interview directly afterwards, and MUSIC Inventory
Evaluation: In terms of performance, the two groups performed not statiscally significantly differently. In terms of motivation, the AR group seemed to score higher, but due to the small sample group, it is not statistically significant.
Results/findings: No real statisical differences between the AR group and control group were observed

Title: Hands On: Experiencing Software Architectures in Virtual Reality
Author(s): C Zirkelbach, A Krause, W Hasselbring
Impact (WHY): Demo of ExplorViz tool using the HTC Vive
Aspect of Software Engineering: Demo of a VR tool for software visualization

Title: Speak to your Software Visualizationâ€”Exploring Component-based Software Architectures in Augmented Reality with a Conversational Interface
Author(s): P Seipel, A Stock, S Santhanam, A Baranowski, N Hochgeschwender, A Schreiber
Venue: Working Conference on Software Visualization
Impact (WHY): Development and architecture of an AR software visualization tool with a converstional (speech recognition) interface
Implementation: The proposed architecture consists of Device, Context Monitor, Controller, Repositoty, and Conversational Services.  When a user utters a command, it goes from the Device to the Controller to the NLU service (which converts it into Intents and Entities). The intent (and entities) are transformed to a query for the Repository, and the resulting response is is sent to the NLG service to convert it back to a natural language response

Title: XRaSE: Towards Virtually Tangible Software using Augmented Reality
Author(s): R Mehra, VS Sharma, V Kaulgud, S Podder
Venue: International Conference on Automated Software Engineering
Impact (WHY): Development of an AR software visualization tool (XRaSE) that renders a visual representation of an input software system. It is supposed to be interactable using gestures for a "tangible" experience
Implementation: Given an input software system, performs static & dynamic analysis to gather a call graph and runtime information. Based on this, an AR graph visualization is generated.
Evaluation: The paper proposes a user study (which hadn't been performed yet)
Considered related work: sv3D, CityVR, city/forest metaphor visualization projects

Title: Integration of properties of virtual reality, artificial neural networks, and artificial intelligence in the automation of software tests: A review
Author(s): E Serna M, E Acevedo M, A Serna A
Venue: Journal of Software Evolution and Process
Impact (WHY): This research identifies the properties of VR (as well as ANNs and AI), and assesses for each to what extent their applicability could be for automated software testing
Implementation: A systematic literature review was performed on the subjects of VR, AI, and ANNs. Based on these findings, and consultation from researchers and specialists, the list of properties for each of these fields was constructed

Title: Live Software Development Environment Using Virtual Reality: A Prototype and Experiment
Author(s): D Amaral, G Domingues, JP Dias, HS Ferreira, A Aguiar, R Nobrega
Venue: Communications in Computer and Information Science
Impact (WHY): Develops a tool which produces a (city) visualization of a software system, along with a structural and execution analysis tool. Also, the study performs an experiment in which the merits of the liveness and visualization are validated
Technical contributions: Analysis tools, and the "main" visualization tool
Implementation: Structural analysis, execution analysis, data from both is made available through an API, that data is used for the visualization of the software throught a city metaphor
Considered related work: CodeCrawler, Jinsight, city metaphor visualizations, VR City

Title: Visualization of Component-Based Software Architectures: A Comparative Evaluation of the Usability in Virtual Reality and 2D
Author(s): M Schaller, A Schreiber
Impact (WHY): Performs a study to compare the usability and effectiveness of VR software visualizations (using an island metaphor) with 2D graph visualizations
Implementation: The two visualization methods were tested and compared according to effectiveness, efficiency, and satisfaction. Effectiveness was measured by having users perform a number of tasks, measuring the task success, and the time on task. Also users were asked to fill in a questionnaire.
Evaluation: 14 participants in total; 7 performed the tasks in the 2D environment, and the other 7 using the VR tool. Three hypotheses are tested: H1: Users are more likely able to complete the tasks in 2D than in VR; H2: Users are more likely able to complete the tasks faster in 2D than in VR; H3: Users are more satisfied while completing the tasks in Virtual Reality than in 2D
Results/findings: For effectiveness, both the 2D and the VR group scored reasonably. In the paper, an immediate conclusion is made that H1 could be confirmed, but the statistically significant reasoning/calculations for this is missing. For efficiency, another hasty conclusion is made based on the results, although here, the difference is very apparent upon looking, so their word can be taken for it. For H3, another quick conclusion is drawn that users were more satisfied by 2D than VR, which based on the results, is also hard to tell whether the difference is statistically significant. The conclusion that H3 does not hold, is somewhat easier to make, probably, so that might be a correct call
Notes: Very quick conlusions in their results. Seemingly no measurement or calculation of statistically significant differences

Title: Implementation of a Quality Measurement Software for Virtual Reality Content on a head mount display
Author(s): K Takayamam, Y Machidori, K Sugita
Venue: 2019 IEEE 10th International Conference on Awareness Science and Technology
Impact (WHY): Develops a Quality Measurement tools for VR

Title: Use of Virtual and Augmented Reality in Design of Software for Airspace
Author(s): T Malich, L Hanakova, V Socha, S Van Den Bergh, M Serlova, L Socha, S Stojic, J Kraus
Venue: 2019 International Conference on Military Technologies
Impact (WHY): Development of a tool for creation and modification of flight routes
